Name: Anthrax
Treatment: Antibiotics: Penicillin, ciprofloxacin (and other quinolones), doxicyclin, ampicillin, imipenem, clindamycin, clarithromycin, vancomycin, chloramphenicol, rifampicin are effective antimicrobials.

Name: C. difficile
Vulnerable: Older adults in hospitals or long-term care facilities who take broad-spectrum antibiotics

Name: Chikungunya
Hotspots: Documented in around 40 countries, mainly Asia and Africa. Outbreak in Italy.
Treatment: No antivirals available. Some drugs have been shown to reduce CHIKV virus in the lab. (interferon-α2b, glycyrrhizin, 6-azauridine and ribavirin)

Name: Cholera
Treatment: Oral rehydration therapy. Preventable with sanitation and water treatment.

Name: Echinococcosis
Treatment: Drugs: benzimidazole compounds such as albendazole
Effectiveness: In most patients, cysts can be completely eliminated using these drugs

Name: Echinococcosis
Hotspots: China (>90% of cases)
Treatment: Drugs: mebendazole, albendazole, praziquantel

Name: Guinea worm disease
Vulnerable: Those who use open stagnant water sources such as ponds
Hotspots: Africa
Treatment: None - prevention only
Effectiveness: Easy to prevent by filtering or treating drinking water to remove fleas

Name: Hand, foot & mouth
Incubation_range: 9-33 for pulmonary syndrome, 12-21 for haemorrhagic fever
Treatment: Vaccines against HFMD caused by EV71 approved 2015 and 2016

Name: Hantavirus
Hotspots: North and South America

Name: Hepatitis A
Hotspots: Developing countries: Central and South America, Africa, India, Middle East and Asia
Treatment: None - prevention only

Name: Bird flu
Vulnerable: Those in areas with infected wild rodents or domestic animals
Treatment: Antibiotics: streptomycin, gentamycin, chloramphenicol
Effectiveness: Effective if treatment begins within 24-36 hours of onset

Name: Seasonal flu
Vulnerable: Pregnant women, children under 59 months, the elderly, individuals with chronic medical conditions

Name: Leishmaniasis
Vulnerable: Malnourished people, migrants or those living near them, those affected by climate change, children under 15
Hotspots: Recent epidemics of cutaneous leishmaniasis in Pakistan (since 2004), Iran (2003), Chad (2007) and Syria.
Resistance: Resistance against sodium antimony gluconate has been documented for all species

Name: Leishmaniasis
Vulnerable: Malnourished people, migrants or those living near them, those affected by climate change, children under 15
Hotspots: Recent epidemics of visceral leishmaniasis in Ethiopia (2005-06), Kenya (2008) and Southern Sudan (2009-2012).
Resistance: Resistance against sodium antimony gluconate has been documented for all species

Name: Leprosy
Treatment: Multidrug therapy: dapsone, rifampicin, Clofazimine

Name: Lyme disease
Hotspots: B. burgdorferi endemic in USA, one area of Canada; Europe, Soviet Union and independant states, Australia, China and Japan
Treatment: Antibiotics. Doxycycline (adults) and amoxicillin (adults and children < 9 years); erythromycin for those allergic to penicillins or tetracyclines

Name: Lymphatic filariasis
Treatment: Drug: Diethylcarbamazine is drug of choice. Also ivermectin, albendazole, and doxycycline. Preventive chemotherapy
Effectiveness: Limited. Diethylcarbamazine has a limited action against adult worms.

Name: Marburg virus disease
Hotspots: Uganda, Angola, DRC
Treatment: None yet proven

Name: Meningitis
Hotspots: The 'meningitis belt' – an area of sub-Saharan Africa stretching from Senegal to Ethiopia
Treatment: Antibiotics including penicillin, ampicillin and ceftriaxone

Name: Meningitis
Hotspots: The 'meningitis belt' – an area of sub-Saharan Africa stretching from Senegal to Ethiopia
Treatment: Antibiotics including penicillin, ampicillin and ceftriaxone

Name: MERS
Vulnerable: Males above the age of 60 with underlying conditions, such as diabetes, high blood pressure and kidney failure, are at a higher risk of severe disease, including death.
Hotspots: Saudi Arabia: Between 2012 and 21 July 2017, 2040 laboratory-confirmed cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome infection were reported to WHO, 82% of whom were reported by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia .

Name: Plague
Treatment: Antibiotics: streptomycin, gentamycin, chloramphenicol
Effectiveness: Effective if treatment begins within 24-36 hours of onset

Name: Pneumonia
Incubation_range: 3-6 days for nonparalytic, 7-21 for paralytic; second source says 7-14, doesn't specify type

Name: Polio
Hotspots: As of 2017 the virus remains in circulation in only three countries in the world – Afghanistan, Pakistan and Nigeria

Name: Rabies
Hotspots: Asia and Africa. India has the highest rate of human rabies in the world, primarily because of stray dogs,[83] whose number has greatly increased since a 2001 law forbade the killing of dogs.[84] Effective control and treatment of rabies in India is also hindered by a form of mass hysteria known as puppy pregnancy syndrome (PPS). Dog bite victims with PPS (both male and female) become convinced that puppies are growing inside them, and often seek help from faith healers rather than from conventional medical services.[85] An estimated 20,000 people die every year from rabies in India — more than a third of the global toll.[84]
Treatment: Vaccine, washing the wound
Effectiveness: Vaccine given before onset of symptoms is 100% effective

Name: Rabies
Hotspots: Asia and Africa. India has the highest rate of human rabies in the world, primarily because of stray dogs,[83] whose number has greatly increased since a 2001 law forbade the killing of dogs.[84] Effective control and treatment of rabies in India is also hindered by a form of mass hysteria known as puppy pregnancy syndrome (PPS). Dog bite victims with PPS (both male and female) become convinced that puppies are growing inside them, and often seek help from faith healers rather than from conventional medical services.[85] An estimated 20,000 people die every year from rabies in India — more than a third of the global toll.[84]
Treatment: Vaccine, washing the wound
Effectiveness: Vaccine given before onset of symptoms is 100% effective

Name: Rotavirus
Peak_year: 2000 (not peak fatality year, but a baseline for comparison)
Hotspots: Four countries (India, Nigeria, Pakistan, and Democratic Republic of Congo) accounted for approximately half (49%) of all estimated rotavirus deaths in 2013

Name: Salmonella
Incubation_range: 2-7 days, sometimes as long as 10; second source says 3-5

Name: Scarlet fever
Treatment: Antibiotics
Resistance: Certain strains of the bacterium have been found to resistant to macrolides, lincomycin, chloramphenicol, tetracyclines and cotrimoxazole

Name: Schistosomiasis
Incubation_range: 1-7 days, usually 1-3 days, second source says 2-3 days
Hotspots: Tropical and subtropical areas of Africa, Asia, South America. 92% of those requiring treatment live in Africa.

Name: Sleeping sickness
Hotspots: Sub-Saharan Africa; 70% of reported cases in last 10 years in Democratic Republic of Congo

Name: Sleeping sickness
Hotspots: Sub-Saharan Africa; 70% of reported cases in last 10 years in Democratic Republic of Congo

Name: Typhoid
Treatment: Antibiotics such as Ciprofloxacin

Name: Typhoid
Treatment: Antibiotics such as Ciprofloxacin

Name: Whooping cough
Hotspots: More than 50% of deaths in Africa
Treatment: Antibiotics. Susceptible to erythromycin, macrolides such as azithromycin and clarithromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, floroquinoles such as ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and gemifloxacin
Resistance: Erythromycin resistant strains have been reported since 1994, but the resistance does not seem to be spreading

Name: Yellow fever
Hotspots: Tropical regions of Africa and South America
Treatment: No anti-viral drug available, but treatment for symptoms of dehydration, liver and kidney failure improves outcomes

Name: Chlamydia
Vulnerable: Females at 15-24 years of age, and males at 20-24 years, men who have sex with men
Hotspots: Developing countries in Africa, South America, Asia and the Caribbean
Treatment: Antibiotics. Susceptible to tetracyclines, macrolides, rifampicin and recent fluoroquinolones
Resistance: Not clearly documented, but multiple drug-resistant strains may be emerging against azithromycin, doxycycline, and ofloxacin

Name: Gonorrhea
Hotspots: Developing countries
Treatment: Antibiotics. Susceptible to third generation cephalosporins, and spectinomycin
Resistance: Often resistant to penicillin and tetracycline

Name: Leishmaniasis
Vulnerable: Malnourished people, migrants or those living near them, those affected by climate change, children under 15
Hotspots: Recent epidemics of visceral leishmaniasis in Ethiopia (2005-06), Kenya (2008) and Southern Sudan (2009-2012).
Resistance: Resistance against sodium antimony gluconate has been documented for all species

Name: Meningitis
Hotspots: The 'meningitis belt' – an area of sub-Saharan Africa stretching from Senegal to Ethiopia
Treatment: Antibiotics including penicillin, ampicillin and ceftriaxone

Name: Sleeping sickness
Hotspots: Sub-Saharan Africa; 70% of reported cases in last 10 years in Democratic Republic of Congo

Name: Anthrax
Treatment: Antibiotics: Penicillin, ciprofloxacin (and other quinolones), doxicyclin, ampicillin, imipenem, clindamycin, clarithromycin, vancomycin, chloramphenicol, rifampicin are effective antimicrobials.

Name: Scarlet fever
Treatment: Antibiotics
Resistance: Certain strains of the bacterium have been found to resistant to macrolides, lincomycin, chloramphenicol, tetracyclines and cotrimoxazole
